beautiful piece by  on serving those who served. “i feel like i’m in vietnam”—reminder covid may lead veterans to reengage with memories that may be distressing. a central part of my practice lately has been asking if they have been thinking more about their service.

i ultimately continued to care for this person in a variety of contexts over the years, and that first experience strengthened our working alliance, despite the pain it caused at first. if the statement came from a place of hate, not anger & suffering i’d likely feel different.

later when i retried the assessment i started by acknowledging how what they said hurt me, and that i wanted to understand how they felt about the experience. the person felt bad and acknowledged they were angry and suffering, and we were able to complete the assessment.

i’m so sorry this happened to you. in the past, when a patient has lobbed something like that at me(different circumstance) i’ve told them that what they said hurt, and that i didn’t feel like i could care for them in this moment in the way i want to. asked them wait in the lobby

the safety data is tremendously clear(both in naturalistic use and scientific studies), efficacy less clear(if you only consider rcts as evidence), and as always, important to include the disclaimer that the scheduling of drugs is absolutely devoid of any and all science.

lack of role models contributes, and i think psychiatrists can be pretty death phobic. in psych residency the deaths/near deaths seen are largely suicide related, so a normal process is patholgized. you’re just not normally exposed to eol in most psych programs, even w/ geri&cl.

psych residents are always surprised that you can do hpm from psych, and the false belief you need to know medicine like an internist. at least a few years ago programs told me they only interview im/fp residents, but i hope that’s changed. 1/2

actiq is definitely not a ‘oh the rep just came by, let me try this out’ kinda medication. i am dubious of the claim that drug reps were convincing folks who didn’t have a primary pain practice to prescribe it. it’s hard to imagine it being any docs first line choice.

i think these folks are also jumping on the ‘bash pharma’ train. 4 actiq, you needed to complete additional rems training & the dosing doesn’t really make sense compared 2 other opioids. in the vast majority of cases it’s not like pcps were slinging it to everyone who walked in.

wavey ideas of understanding someone’s experience and helping them to feel better. that’s my hot take.

i have no idea how the therapy works, just like i have no idea how any of our therapies work. it’s all built on theoretical frameworks grounded in a cultural context. cbt/pe isn’t more real than anything else—is a schema more legit than a superego? they are all somewhat hand

+ptsd that showed similar reductions in trauma symptoms. it would be amazing if every trauma therapist was trained in all ebts and allowed pts to pick what worked best for them, not say you must complete one modality. i think saying emdr is junk shames people who benefit from it.

lee and cuijpers did an analysis showing the benefit of bls about 10 years ago i think. afaik several meta-analyses show similar efficacy for emdr to other tf-therapies. im not aware of a recent rct comparing cpt/pe/emdr, but there was a paper looking at emdr and pe in psychosis

that’s a hot take from the 1990s—now there are numerous rcts and systematic reviews documenting emdrs efficacy. yes, many of the components are similar to other tf modalities, just like many therapeutic approaches share core concepts.
yay!!! congrats!!!

what i’m suggesting is we don’t know someone is not uncomfortable, even with sedation. sedation is an important part of our attempts to keep folks in what we think is comfort, but we can also explicitly acknowledge the trauma and sometimes violent things we do to help folks heal.
*whispers to other physicians* try reading the nursing notes if you aren’t going to the bedside.

there are so many of these instances in our everyday documentation. all seem to dehumanize/deemphasize the patient’s experience. i might not be able to change the clinical picture, but i can be aware and document my being witness to the suffering. what other boxes do we check?

can we stop writing “pt comfortable on the ventilator”? being sedated is not the same as comfort. i often wonder if we deploy this phrase to not have to think about the person’s internal experience, or our discomfort with using invasive interventions that cause harm.

today we are excited to focus on the challenges we are having with telehealth and the disparities that emerge during care. how does lack of access(no hi-speed internet, land line only, etc) and reduced hearing/visual acuity impact the care we provide to pallicovid pts/families?

i think it will take some pretty terrible events to get to that point, but it's in the back of my mind. a 'bug out bag' for when hospice cant be there.

i think you can also have a covid plan and a non covid plan. what is hard is to predict what resources will be available in the future, such that these might not be choices people will even be able to make.

i think having some early conversations re:molst, naming hcp. in some ways i think the conversations can be similar. 'given your chronic health conditions, i'm worried about how this might impact you. what thoughts have you been thinking about your health as all this unfolds?'

i have begun to tell patients that as things change it's really hard to predict what will happen, but that in some situations it may be harder to honor certain wishes. i've been going over my outpatient roster to make sure folks have completed molst forms. 4/n

for some of the patients i've preemptively talked about hospice. for those who have expressed clear wishes to avoid hospitalization, i have framed this as i want us to be prepared, and having hospice in place now will help if things change rapidly. 3/n

i also have been sharing with pts what i'm doing to care for myself, to model but also many express worry about how i'm managing. since this is something 'we are all in together' i spend some time assuring patients that i can hold their worries and concerns and take care of me 2/

it's a really good point, and something i have been thinking a lot about the last week. several things that come up: 1st off i spend a bit of time to process with patients what it's like to be doing video/phone visits for the foreseeable future and ask how they feel about it 1/n

insurance companies may place restrictions of paying for buprenorphine if there isn’t a visit every 28 days, so would be interesting to see if covid19 changes how this is handled

the good thing is if the person was hospitalized then an x waiver isnt a necessity to prescribe while inpatient. prescribers also forget that buprenorphine is schedule iii--and this seems like a good a time as any to put refills on bup to limit unnecessary clinic visits.
thanks for the clarification!

add to that the number of preparatory, drug sessions and integration sessions you are looking at 40hrs of contact hours with two therapists. nothing in the phase iii protocol comes remotely close to “quick fix”.

using language like “quick fix” is the same shaming approach that proponents of abstinence based txs take to people on buprenorphine/methadone. why can’t we simply focus on finding a wide range of tx options that work for a wide range of people?
